Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Sheriff Wyner...

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Afternoon, Miz Munson.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: ...Mackatee Funthes?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Oh yeah, believe I do.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Uh-huh...

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Well--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: He--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Uh-huh...

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: I could--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: No ma'am--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: It's been disturbin' Othar then, has it?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: I don't think I--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Yes'm--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Mm-mm--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Help him?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Well, we're here to help...

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: No ma'am.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Many what ma'am?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: No ma'am--

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Mm-hm.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Yes ma'am.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Ma'am?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I do beg your pardon?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Pickles...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I am so terribly sorry, madam. But won't the feline eventually tire of his lonely perch and, pining for his master's affection, return on his own initiative?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well then couldn't we perhaps offer him kitty treats and enticements, or if not foodstuffs perhaps squeaky little toys of the kind formerly manufactured in Hong Kong but now produced in the other so-called "Little Tigers"...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...of the Pacific Rim? The point bein', do we have to actually ascend the tree--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Police...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: No need to call the authorities. I did this often as a youth -- why, I was a positive lemur... Here, kitty...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I wouldn't dream of it... harmless little felix domesticus... Come to G.H...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I thank you, madam, for your act of kindness.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I certainly did and I do apologize no end. Allow me to present myself, uh, formally: Goldthwait Higginson Dorr, Ph.D.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Beg your pardon, ma'am?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: No no, Ph.D. is a mark of academic attainment. It is a degree of higher learning bestowed, in my case, in recognition of my mastery of the antique languages of Latin and Greek. I also hold a number of other advanced degrees including the baccalaureate from a school in Paris, France, called the Sorbonne.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I have not had that privilege.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: That's very gener--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Indeed.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Perhaps when my head has recovered from its... buffeting. Mrs. Munson, are you at all curious as to why I darkened your door, as the expression has it, on this lovely camelia-scented morn?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I quite understand. The fact is that I saw the sign on your window advertising a room to let, and it is the only such sign among the houses of this charming, charming street.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I quite understand. Madam, you are addressing a man who is quiet -- and yet not quiet, if I may offer a riddle...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Perhaps you can show me the room, Mrs. Munson, and allow me to explain.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: You see, madam, I am currently on sabbatical from the institution where I teach -- the University of Mississippi at Hattiesburg. I am taking a year off to indulge my passion -- I don't believe that is too strong a word -- for the music of the Renaissance. I perform in -- and have the honor of directing -- a period instrument ensemble that performs at Renaissance fairs and other cultural fora...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...thoo-out central and southern Mississippi. We perform on the instruments for which the music was originally composed, in the belief that... that... Why, this is lovely...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The word "band" would be, in this context, something of an anachronism. Though we do play together -- hence the word "ensemble" -- the nature of the music is such that one would hesitate to apply the epithet "band" with its connotations of jangling rhythm and ear-popping amplification.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madam, I shudder. I quake. The revulsion I feel for modern popular music, and all other manifestations of contemporary decay, is, I have no doubt, the equal of y'own. Why, we play music that was composed to the greater glory of God. Devotional music. Church music.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well-inspired by the gospels, certainly. The vintage, of course, is no more recent than the Rococo.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: But I certainly don't propose to inflict our rehearsals on you. May I enquire -- do you have a root cellar?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, yes, yes, this looks promising...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh, indeed, but that only improves the acoustics...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Marvelous. These earthen walls are ideal for baffling the higher registers of the, uh, lute and, uh, sackbutt. That's why so much music of the cinquecento was played in crypts and catacombs. Yes, this will do nicely...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...This is perfect. This is more than perfect. I can scarcely contain my glee.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Allow me to pay you a week in advance. Allow me to pay you two weeks in advance. Allow me to pay you a month in advance. I cannot countenance the thought of these charming apartments being tenanted by someone unappreciative of their special je ne sais quoi.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...You wouldn't believe this shit, sometimes even out here on the casino floor you gonna find sanitary napkin shit stuck there, Tucks, I don't know what the fuck people do while they're gambling here man.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I ain't peelin' funky shit with my human hands, man. That's a prescription for disease and viruses and shit, attackin' y'insides.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: You gotta do it. Mr. Gudge checks everything. Man is a motherfuck. Shit -- looka this.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...You keep an eye out, man. I found a hundred-dollar chip once.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuck that, man. I ain't pawin' through used Tucks for a fi' dollar chip.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: I said it was a hundred.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Man, your guts gonna turn to soup'n leak outcha fuckin' asshole.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: This tunnel leads back onto land. To the office for all the people work for Mannex. Mannex Corporation. Owns the Lady Luck 'n three other boats...

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...This is where they think on their corporate shit, Gudge and them.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...The lights is ugly but it ain't as many Tucks.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...YO, motherfuck! Lemme in!

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: Kiss my ass.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: This is where they count the dough. You try to take any of it Elron there shoot your ass.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...This place is a fuckin' pigsty. You a pig, man, nothin' but a squeaky ol' motherfuckin' pig...

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...You got fuckin' Kocoa Krispies in ya uniform man, still got breakfast there and you eatin' motherfuckin' lunch.

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...You a disgrace before motherfuckin' God...

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: ...You a motherfuck-- oh, hello Mr. Gudge, how we be this mornin'?

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Funthes. How's the new man?

Speaker: weemack
Dialogue: He is a cleaning motherfucker, man!

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Is that a fact.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Scrub two! Scrub three! Four, Mountain!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: ...Props!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: ...The goddamn thing's canteen fell off. It would have been a good take.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Okay. Okay. We're prepared for that...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ... Mountain, bring Otto with the apparatus.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: What the hell is this?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: World War I vintage gas mask. It's authentic. Strapped on, of course, so it can't fall off. The animal is free to be as active as he wants, doesn't inhibit his movement, and I think it really sells the whole doughboy thing--

Speaker: director
Dialogue: It looks like a fucking joke.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Nnnnrnff!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No, nothing, uh... you're absolutely right, the gas mask is a whimsical concept--

Speaker: director
Dialogue: How the hell does it eat when it gets to the Kennel Rations?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, you're absolutely right-

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Don't let the client see this.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course not, that would be inappropriate--

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Or the Humane fucker.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No no--

Speaker: director
Dialogue: They'll shut the fucking spot down, Pancake. Put the goddamn canteen back on. That says he's a soldier. Dented tin canteen. Just tie the damn thing to his collar.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Easiest thing in the world. I just thought -- but the canteen is much better. Good concept. Let's go with that--

Speaker: director
Dialogue: What's he doing?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, he's uh... Just breathe normally, Otto.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: The fucking dog can't breathe.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Oh, he can breathe, that thing is -- just breathe normally, Otto.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: The fucking dog cannot breathe! Get that fucking thing off him!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course. Easiest thing in the world.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...It's on good and tight, I, uh... Just breathe normally, Otto.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Get the fucking thing off him!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Don't have my Leatherman. Mountain! Give me your Leatherman! Chop chop!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Get the fucking thing off him! Chitra, make sure the Humane fucker doesn't come over here! Bring him to craft services!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Good idea! Ice water, treats-

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Not the dog, you idiot! The Humane fucker! Distract him!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Right! Of course!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Oh my god, he's bleeding!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No, that's me -- I -- the Leatherman... here we go.

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Put up a couple solids here -- I don't want the client seeing this!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Come on, Otto!

Speaker: director
Dialogue: Otto is fucking dead!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Mountain, have electric run me a stinger! Don't give up on me, Otto! Mountain, I need two live leads!

Speaker: mountain girl
Dialogue: Clark, the gennie's a hundred yards away!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Goddamnit! Otto's gonna have brain damage in about ninety seconds! Okay!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Kiss of life!

Speaker: quarterback
Dialogue: Delta thirty-seven. On four!

Speaker: team
Dialogue: Huh!

Speaker: quarterback
Dialogue: Okay, Epsilon twenty-two! You the man!... Hey! BUTTHEAD!

Speaker: quarterback
Dialogue: You the man!

Speaker: team
Dialogue: Huh!

Speaker: vietnamese woman
Dialogue: Yao gin nyap!

Speaker: vietnamese woman
Dialogue: Hi-Ho.

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: I know you all remember that when Moses came down the mountain, carrying the word a God, come down that Sinai peak, he caught those Israelites red- handed. What he catch 'em doin'? He caught 'em worshipping a golden calf.

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...He caught 'em with their backs turned on God!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...He caught 'em worshipping a FALSE God! A God of EARTHLY things! He caught them Israelites in DECLINE!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...Because backslidin' is DECLINE, brothers and sisters! You hear talk these days, and I know you've heard this talk, you hear talk of DECLINE, well all that means is we done turned our back on God!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...People say civilization doin' this, civilization doin' that, civilization in DECLINE! Well it ain't no civilization! It ain't no them! It's US, brothers and sisters!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...It's what's in our hearts, each and every one of us when we like them Israelites! Slidin' awa-a-a-ay down that Godly slope, slippin' and slidin' toward the mire and muck a the stinkhole of greed -- that's DECLINE!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...And what did Moses do when he saw those declinin' backslidin' never- mindin' sinners?

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...Moses SMOTE those sinners in his wrath yes he did!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...Y'all know what smote is! I smite! You smite! He smites! We done smote!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...To smite is to go UPSIDE the head!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...Because sometimes, brothers and sisters, that is the ONLY way!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...To smite is to reMIND! We got to STOP that decline! And scramble back UP to the face a the almighty Gyod!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...'Stead a worshippin' that GOLDEN calf, that earthly TRASH on that GARBAGE island! That GARBAGE island in that shadowland WAY outside the Kingdom a God!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...That GARBAGE island where scavenger birds feast on the bones a the backslidin' damned!

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: ...And so, let us pray...

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: Why thank you, Sister Rose.

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: Oh now ladies...

Speaker: preacher
Dialogue: Oh now you gracious ladies.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: My dear Mrs. Munson, I do so hope this is not an inopportune time for our first practice--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I beg your-- Oh!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...No no, no bereavement, though it is so kind of you to enquire. No, the hearse is simply a vehicle commodious enough to accommodate all of the members of our ensemble. And of course our instruments, contrived in an age ignorant of miniaturization...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Let me introduce you to my friends, my colleagues, these devoted and passionate musicians... This is Gawain MacSam, our bassoonist...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...General Nguyen Pham Doc, viola da gamba...

Speaker: general
Dialogue: So sorry.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Clark Pancake -- a multi- instrumentalist, but with his remarkable embosser Clark specializes in wind instruments, and is especially accomplished on the French horn...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...And, finally, Aloysius "Lump" Hudson. Lump is our sackbuttist and -- thank you, Lump -- I see you've also brought my fiddle...

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Here's your fiddle, Doctor.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh no. Oh no no no no no. No, we shall recuse ourselves to the basement where we shall be -- I think here the expression is uniquely appropriate...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...as quiet as the crypt.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: What do you think, General? Present any problems?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Good then.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...All right, gentlemen, why don't we all crowd around and go over the plan.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...This, gentlemen, is the Lady Luck, gambling den, cash cow, Sodom of the Mississippi delta -- and the focus of our little exercise. Here is Orchard Street...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...and here is the residence of Marva Munson, the charming lady whom y'all met moments ago. Gentlemen...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...You... are... here. Now. This brings us to this square...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Gentlemen, I believe you are all aware that the Solons of the State of Mississippi, to wit, its legislature, have decreed that no gaming establishment shall be erected within its borders upon dry land. They may, however, legally float upon any watercourse defining a state boundary. But while the gambling activity itself is restricted to riverboats, no such restriction applies to the functions ancillary to this cash besotted bidnis. The casino's offices, locker rooms, facilities to cook and clean, and most importantly its counting houses- the reinforced, secret, and super secure repositories of the lucre -- may all be situated... wherever. Gawain -- where is wherever?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Say wha?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Where is the money?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Oh. End of every shift pit boss brings the cash down to the hold of the ship in the locked cash box; once a day all the cash boxes're moved to the counting room.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And where is the counting room?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Well, uh... in that square there. Where you pointing.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And what, to flog a horse that if not at this point dead is in mortal danger of expirin', does the dotted square represent?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...Offices. Underground.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Underground... Mmm... During the casino's hours of operation the door to the counting room is fiercely guarded, and the door itself is of redoubtable Pittsburgh steel; when the casino is closed the entire underground complex is locked up and the armed guard retreats to the casino's main entrance. There, then, far from the guard, reposes the money, cosseted behind a five-inch-thick steel portal, yes, but the walls, gentlemen, the walls of that room, are but humble masonry, behind which is only the soft loamy soil deposited over the centuries by Ol' Man, the meanderin' Mississip', as it fanned its way back and forth across this great alluvial plain...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...This earth.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Any questions?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Yes, Lump?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: What, uh... what does "cosseted" mean?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The General here, whose curriculum vitae compahends massive tunneling experience thoo the soil of his native French-Indochina, will direct our little ol' tunnelin' operation.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Clark Pancake, while a master of none, is a jack of all those trades corollary to our aim. He will be doin' such fabricatin' and demolition work as our little caper shall require.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Happy to be on board.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gawain is the proverbial "inside man". He has managed to secure a berth on the custodial staff of the Lady Luck, thereby placin' himself in a position to perform certain chores whose precise nature needn't detain us here, but whose performance shall guide this expedition to its happy conclusion.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Ya damn skippy.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And this brings us to Lump. To look at Lump you might wonder, what function could he possibly fill, what specialized expertise could he possibly offer, to our merry little ol' band a miscreants. Well gentlemen, in a project of such magnitude and such risks, it is traditional -- nay, it is imperative -- to enlist the services of a hooligan, a goon, an ape, a physical brute, who will be our security, our fist, our batterin' ram. Lump is our blunt instrument, and on all our behalfs I wish him a warm Mississippi welcome.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Thanks, Professor.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well gentlemen, here you are, men of different backgrounds and differing talents, men with, in fact only two things in common: one, you all saw fit to answer my little advertisement in the Memphis Scimitar, and, two, you are all going to be, in consequence, very very incredibly rich. Let us revel in our adventure, gentlemen. Let us make beautiful music together. And above all, gentlemen, let us keep it to ourselves. What we say in this root cellar, let it stay in this root cellar.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: There's no "I" in "team".

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Lump has a very excellent point.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: No no, madam, we were about to take a break anyway. The glissandi on this particular piece are technically very demanding and I think we would all welcome a moment of relaxation.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I, uh...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: That man plays one bitch barrelful a sackbutt. Ain't no one can blow the tenor sackbutt like Lump, hoowee! goes at that thing like it was a pu-- uh, like it was a woman! Goddamn! He--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Sadly, Gawain is given to--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: As well you should, ma'am. But Gawain at times is so far transported by his love of the music of the early Renaissance as to--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I understand your--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Certainly not, madam. I understand your indignation. And I was offering explanation, not excuse. I myself am offended by those who cannot find the proper words to express themselves and have recourse to--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Don't you be explainin' me, dawg! You can't look into my mind, cape man!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, yes...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...A fiery lad! But then Youth is fiery! A fact often remarked upon by the poets of the Romantic era.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Did he?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh, I am indeed--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Ah.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Indeed not.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...I don't suppose Othar ever turned his hand -- or, uh, heh-heh-heh, turned his lip -- to the shofar?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...The ceremonial ram's horn, sounded by the priests of the Hebrews?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...Don't let this uniform fool ya--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You don't need to be gamblin', honey, you lookin' at a sure thing. They call me Mr. 21, baby, 'cause that's how I measure up. I am the original black Jack, honey, accept no substitutions. You can pull my lever all day long, sweet mama, I ain't never gonna come up lemons. That's right, sugar, you can blow on my dice any ol' time.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: But Mr. Gudge, she had an ass that could pull a bus. This lady was fine, fine, dandy, divine.

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: I don't care how big her ass was, MacSam. You're fired.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Say what?

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: There is no fraternizing with customers on the Lady Luck. Clean out your locker.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: But Gudge-

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Get out of here. You're fired.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You can't fire me. I sue your ass!

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Sue me? For what?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Sue you for fuckin' punitive damages, man!

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Punitive damages.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Ya damn skippy. I know you firin' my ass 'cause I'm black!

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Everyone on the custodial staff is black, MacSam. Your replacement's gonna be black. His replacement will no doubt be black.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuckin' judge is gonna be black, motherfucker, that's who gonna be black! You gonna stand tall before the man!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh my. Oh my my my my my. This is a severe setback. I am distraught. I am more than distraught, I am devastated. Oh my, this is quite the monkey-wrench heaved into the meticulously engineered construct of our little escapade.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Yeah, it fucks things up.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I am beside myself. I am at a positive loss for words.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You still talkin' okay though.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Have you all decided?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh madam, we must have waffles. We must all have waffles forthwith!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Oh we must think. We must all have waffles and think, each and every one of us to the very best of his ability! Perhaps if you apologized to the man and gave him flowers, or perhaps a fruit basket, with a card depicting a misty seascape and inscribed with a sentiment.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Shit, man, it ain't about apologizin'! He fired me 'cause I'm black!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: He can't do that. You could sue him. Open and shut case.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuckin' A.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Man's a fuckin' bigot.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well then, perhaps, surely, a chocolate assortment has been known to warm the heart of even the most hardened misanthrope, especially if it's a premium chocolate, imported, say, from Switzerland, or the Netherlands, or some other of the so- called "Low" countries be they Dutch or Flemish or Walloon--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Walloon my ass, the man ain't gonna roll over for a fuckin' candy bar!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: I'm afraid there's a setback on the tunneling front too. We've run into a pretty large rock, and--

Speaker: general
Dialogue: -- Rock!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: ...Very bad.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh my my, it seems that the poet was right: Troubles never singly come.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Oh, we can get through the rock, no worries there. Simplest thing in the world. Why we blow right through it; I've got a pyro license, we bore a hole in the rock, pack in a little plastique; igneous blows pretty good, and we--

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Is he gonna want a piece of the action?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Who?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...Igneous?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Yes, Mountain, we were just talking about that, and some plastique.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...The fuck is this?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: This is Mountain Girl. Mountain is my right hand. She helps me with ordnance. Helps me with damn near everything.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You brought your bitch to the waffle house?!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I confess myself to be puzzled as well. I thought we all understood that, so far as our little enterprise is concerned, mum, as the saying would have it, is the word--

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course. I understand that. But this is Mountain...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I don't keep secrets from Mountain. That's not how you maintain a loving, caring relationship.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You brought your bitch to the waffle house?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...Man brings his bitch to the waffle house!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Look, you, I'll thank you to stop referring to Mountain that way. She's the other half of my life.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Everybody lookin' at me like I'm a fuck-up, losin' that sorry-ass job, and this motherfucker bring his bitch to the waffle house!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: You son of a bitch punk! Shut your goddamn mouth!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Come and get me motherfuck! Come on, baby, let's get it on!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, please!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Gentlemen, this sort of behavior does you no credit in the eyes of your colleagues, or in those of the other patrons of this waffle house!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Nobody talks to Mountain Girl that way. She had an abusive family!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuck you, man.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Little punk. I got syrup on my safari jacket.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I propose that we consider the matter of this woman, Mountain Water, to be--

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Mountain Girl.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I am so very sorry. I propose that we consider this matter to be closed, and we shall chose to trust her, since we now have no choice, and since she shall share only in Mr. Pancake's portion of the booty.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course. Wouldn't have it any other way.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Damn right you won't.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Up yours, punk.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen! And the manner of disposing of our igneous impediment is also settled. That leaves only the question of Gawain retrieving his job.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Couldn't you just bribe the guy?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes yes, I must confess, madam, that often I feel more at home in these ancient volumes than I do in the hustle-bustle of our modern world. To me, paradoxically, the literature of the so-called "dead tongues" has more currency than this mornin's newspaper.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: In these books...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...In these volumes, there is the accum'lated wisdom a mankind which succours me when the day is hard or the night lonely and long.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh yes, the Good Book, mm. I have found reward in its pages. But for me there are other good books as well; the heavy volumes of Antiquity, freighted with the insights of Man's glorious age. And then of course I love, love, love the works of Mr. Ed G'Allan Poe.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh no, madam, noooo. Not of this world, true; he lived in a dream, an ancient dream...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "Helen, they beauty is to me Like those Nicean barks a yore That gently, o'er a perfumed sea, The weary, wayworn wanderer bore To his own native shore... "

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: One doesn't know who Helen was, though I picture her as bein' very, very extremely... pale.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Miz Munson, I was tryin' to think of some way of expressin' my gratitude to you for takin' in...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...this weary, wayworn wanderer...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...It's just a modest little ol' present, why it's practically nothing at all.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh no madam, I blush. I melt. No, I just happened to hear of this gospel concert tomorrow night, The Mighty Mighty Clouds of Joy, and I thought you and a friend from church, perhaps...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The concert is up in Memphis, but I have arranged for a car service to transport you thither and, needless to say, back home at the concert's termination. My friends and I will be rehearsing here tomorrow evening so you needn't worry about the security of your charming little old house...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: ...to let you know I had a word with WeeMack. He says he gonna comply with your request, keep the music down and neighborly.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: So you have a pleasant evening now, and just let us know--

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Ma'am, I'm a little pressed for time--

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Someone was here, ma'am?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, maybe I'll catch him next time...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Very neat.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Ma'am, I really have to...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: ...be gettin' back...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Miz Munson, my pager just went off...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: 'Fraid I gotta respond...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: ...I'll try to meet your friend some other time.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well that was very... refreshing... As you know...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...we academics are inordinately fond of wedgin' ourselves into confined spaces. At Yale the students will see how many of their number they can enclose in a telephone booth; Harvard, a broom closet.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: There was the goldfish-swallowin' craze, of course, a different but related phenomenon... Ahem... I hope I didn't spill any tea...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: It's just my way of sayin', well, goddamnit, I don't know what it's like walkin' in your shoes, bein' all tightass and all, and you don't know what it's like to walk in my shoes, but, well...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You know, there's the custodian, and then there's the man inside the custodian, y'understand what I'm sayin'...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...and that man has needs, dig, and I guess those needs, Mr. Gudge, which they usually involve women with big asses, well those motherfuckin' needs sometimes well up over the custodian like the motherfuckin' Johnstown Flood. But my point is it ain't gonna happen again. Not if it's humanly possible...

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Hmm...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: But Jesus, if you'd seen the ass on that girl, Mr. Gudge, you'd a wanted her sitting on your face too.

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: Well, we're all human.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Ya damn skippy.

Speaker: gudge
Dialogue: This apology buys you a one-week probationary period. Stay away from the customers, MacSam.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: The drill bit's getting awfully hot. Gawain, maybe you could fill a hudson sprayer and spritz it down while I drill.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuck you, man, I ain't your house nigger. I'm the inside man!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Look, are you gonna have a bug up your ass for the rest of the time we work together?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I'll get the sprayer.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No no, me and this gentleman here have to get square. Let me tell you something, MacSam. You wanna know something?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I don't wanna know shit from you.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: I'm gonna tell you how I came down to Mississippi. Wasn't born here, you know. I'm from Scranton, Pennsylvania...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Nnnff!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Scranton, Pennsylvania. Came down here in 1964. Greyhound Bus. With the Freedom Riders. You know who the Freedom Riders were, MacSam?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I don't give a shit who they were. Just tell me when they gonna leave.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: The Freedom Riders, my fine young man, were a group of concerned liberals from up North -- whites, Negros, and yes, Jewish people -- all working together, just like we are here. Concerned citizens who came down here so that local black people could have their civil liberties. So that people like you could have the vote.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You know what, man?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: What, brother?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I don't vote. So fuck you.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Why you fucking--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: And the bus you rode in on!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: That's it!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Let's step outside, MacSam!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, madam?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh madam, you are too kind. Our music, however, is -- how shall I put it? -- rather Roman in its outlook; many of our pieces were commissioned by the Holy See.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Indeed. Excuse me, one moment, ma'am, and I shall see you off...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...If you gentlemen can labor harmoniously in the course of my absence, then perhaps upon my return we shall be prepared to explode that vexin' ol' piece a igneous.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: He's the motherfuckin' piece of igneous.

Speaker: rosalie
Dialogue: Oh my, that's an awful lot of letters.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well of course in my youth I was simply known as Goldthwait...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: All right, safety meeting, let's listen up. General, could you hand me the prima cord and the compound there. Before we set the charge we'll run through our procedure.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I have earplugs for whoever wants them. Just wedge them in your ears. Now here we have -- not yet, Lump.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Now. Prima cord. Gelatinite. C4. Time comes, we pack the hole in the rock with the C4 and insert two leads. A...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...and B.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Charge comes from a battery that is inside this plunger. Ordinary auto battery, you can pick it up at Sears, easiest thing in the world...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I remember my father telling me -- and it is one of the few memories I retain of the man, from one of his visits home, and how I do cherish it -- he said, "Goldthwait, you are not formed as other little boys."

Speaker: rosalie
Dialogue: Mm-mm.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: G.H. number two was self-educated; he had no career, as such, though the state recognized the breadth of his readin' by making him librarian at the state nervous hospital in Meridian, where he was a distinguished inmate.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: This is the same procedure we will be using when we collapse the tunnel after entering the casino vault and returning to the root cellar.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...This is for your own protection, so pay close attention. Once these materials are combined only the professionals may handle them. That means me, or the General. Separately they are harmless-completely inert. Why, you could light this stuff on fire, hit it with a hammer--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I'm... quite sure... that there is... no cause for alarm...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Why, I'm not even absolutely certain that I heard anything at all.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well, something, perhaps, but...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...nothing that need discompose us, was the sense I was trying to convey...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Miz Munson, I will not have you missing your musical recital. Why, you go ahead now. Miz Funthes, you as well, I beg of you...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...I shall call the gas company, or the water company, or whatever subterranean utility is implicated in this little... occurrence... I shall see to the matter... as only a highly educated classicist could.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Blood, Professor! Oh my God! Blood!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...why, it's nothing to make a fuss about. Perfectly all right... happens all the time...

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You gotta go find it, dipshit!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...No, no. Really, I'm perfectly all right.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Perfectly all right? You just blew your fucking finger off!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Sure, but--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Well get back down there and find it, man! I ain't pickin' up your goddamn finger!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I gather there was a premature detonation--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: They can sew that shit back on, jack! Like that guy his wife cut his dick off! Just sewed that motherfucker back on!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course. Simplest thing in the world. Microsurgery--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Saw that motherfucker in a porno! Thing still works!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Oh yes, they have remarkable abilities in the, uh...

Speaker: rosalie
Dialogue: Mmmm-hm.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I propose that we get our fallen comrade to the hospital, and the General shall follow when he manages to recover the severed digit.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: I don't know what all the fuss is about.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The house is perfectly in order, but we need medical attention for Mr. Pancake who, during the disturbance, pinched his finger in a valve of the sackbutt.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The General is even now exercising every effort to retrieve your mischievous little pet. Please go, go and enjoy your concert, and we shall see you later in the evening. Au revoir, mes dames!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...here, this afternoon, having successfully blasted that little ol' rock to pieces during Miz Munson's choir practice.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Clark, perhaps you can run us through the game plan for what remains of our tunnelin'.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Just the usual spadework until we hit the masonry of the vault, and then we drill through.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And will you be able to wield the drill with your maimed extremity?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Oh, I should think so, it's only one finger. Inhibits me in doing finer work, of course. I'll always have to live with that... Ahem. Maybe, and I'm just thinking out loud here, maybe since, as you say, it will present problems later...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, Clark?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, maybe -- and this is something I've talked over with Mountain Girl, and she agrees with me, so it's not just one person's opinion -- maybe I should get a little extra compensation for the accident.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Somewhat larger share. Why, if this were any other line of work I'd be getting workmen's comp, wouldn't I? Might even have a pretty good lawsuit.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You gonna sue yaself for blowin' off your finger?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well that is simply asinine--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes but you see, Clark, this is not what you just called "some other line of work."

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: But if it were--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: This is a criminal enterprise, not to put too fine a point on it, entailin' all manner a risks not involved in honest labor. Governmental regulations an' civic safeguards cannot be assumed to apply to antisocial pursuits.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Yeah, but he lost his finger.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: We don't give a shit! Man can blow his own dick off, don't make no nevermind to us! We don't gotta pay the man for goin' around blowin' off body parts! Getcha head outcha ass, man!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Look, you--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I think that in this instance Gawain has a very excellent point. I--

Speaker: general
Dialogue: No extra share!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, okay, majority rules, like I say, it was just a trial balloon. Hand's not so bad really, I even get some phantom feeling.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You pull on your prick you get phantom feeling. Greedy motherfuck.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Now that that matter is settled, let us synchronize our watches before Gawain reports to work. In... twenty seconds... it will be twelve-sixteen exactly... fifteen...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: It will be twelve-fifteen?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: No, in fifteen seconds -- now eleven seconds -- it will be twelve- sixteen... eight...

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Professor?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Six... five -- yes, Lump?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I don't have a watch.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Me, dickwad.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Well ain't that somethin'.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Hnnnn. Arrunggggh! Rnffff.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Mmmmnggh!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...IBS!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...Say what?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: IBS! Irritable Bowel Syndrome! Is there a men's room down here?!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Oh man, you shouldn't be using the men's room--

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Or a lady's room! IBS! Quickly!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You shoulda shit back in the house, man! We don't want Elron finding you in the goddamn crapper!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No choice! Quickly! It's a medical condition!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You are disgusting, man. All right, follow me.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Feel thirty pounds lighter.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Thank you for being so understanding. Not everyone is, of course, which is why the biggest challenge of IBS is educating the public. Afflicts over two million people yet most of us have never heard of it. And it strikes without regard to age, gender or race.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Oh fuck, man, I don't wanna know about it.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: That's the kind of attitude we're fighting.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Well maybe you should sign me up, man, 'cause you startin' to irritate my bowel.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I guess I never told you, that's how Mountain Girl and I met. They had an IBS Weekend at Grossinger's, in the Catskills. Of course the tourist business up there has suffered, with the demise of the Borscht Belt. So they have different promotions, mixers, so on. This was a weekend for Irritable Bowel singles to meet and support each other and share stories.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Man, I don't wanna hear a single one a them stories.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, some of them are very--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Not one fuckin' story! You one fucked- up motherfucker! You--

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Hey, lookit that.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Huh. Looks like an Ikegami.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Oh yeah. Mm-hm. I'm not sure whether it's broadcasting...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Hard wire...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Look, I didn't choose to have IBS--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Shut the fuck up!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: There's no cure, you know. Only control. Lifelong condition. Not complaining, just fact. And I did meet Mountain.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Grab your bag and get in that fucking hole!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Welcome back, gentlemen, mission accomplished I see. I am so very very delighted...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Congratulations. Congratulations. I have some cold duck on ice for the occasion.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Maybe we could have something to drink, too.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Motherfucker can't stop talking, can't stop shitting. Motherfucker tell everyone about his motherfuckin' asshole. No one gives a shit about his asshole. Nobody interested in another man's asshole. Or his bitch's.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, to we few. We who have shared each other's company, each other's care, each other's joy, and who now reap the fruits of our communal effits, shoulder to shoulder, from each accordin' to his abilities so forth whatnot. We have had our little diffences along the way, it's true, but I like to think they have only made us value one another the more, each coming to understand and appreciate the other's unique qualities, potencies, and, yes, foibles. I suggest that we shall look back upon this caper one day, one distant day, grandchildren dandled upon our knee, and perhaps a tear will form, and we shall say, Well, with wit, and grit, and no small amount of courage, we accomplished something on that day, a feat of derring-do, an enterprise not ignoble -- we, merry band, unbound by the constraints of society and the prejudices of the common ruck, we happy few. Gentlemen -- to us!

Speaker: men
Dialogue: To us!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Charge should've gone off already.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I do beg your pardon?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: The charge to collapse the tunnel. I set it for eight minutes.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well that time, and more, has most certainly elapsed.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I need not remind you of the importance of obliterating any trace of a connection between the vault and this house. It was of the essence of this plan that it should appear that the money had simply vanished. Without a trace. Spirited away, as it were, by ghosts.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Of course. I understand.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: The conundrum of the undisturbed yet empty vault, the unsolvable riddle of the sealed yet violated sanctum, is of the utmost importance not only to make our caper innelectually satisfying. It is also exigent as a matter of practical fact: I remind you that if a tunnel is ever found leading to this house, this house's owner knows all of your names.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: She certainly does.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Therefore -- to draw the unavoidable conclusion -- someone shall have to reenter the tunnel to reset that charge.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Huh.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Nnnnrungh...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Huh?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...What the--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...You just fart?

Speaker: elron
Dialogue: Heh-heh-heh.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Properly speaking, madam, we have been surprised; you are taken aback. Though I acknowledge that the sense you intend is gaining currency through increasing use.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...You have returned from your devotions betimes.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: She saw everything. She saw our hole...

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...She saw our hole, Professor!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes... Yes...

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: What do we do?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well, first, my dear boy, we follow the General's example...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...and refrain from panic. Secondly, we cooly, calmly, collectedly think... think...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Hsst... Madam...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Mrs. Munson, if I might have a word...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I assure you I shall be--

Speaker: ladies
Dialogue: Mm-hm.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: She shall be down shortly...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Tea. Dainties.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Professor?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, Lump?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I can't really play the buttsack.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madame -- or rather, mesdames -- you will have to accept our apologies for failing to perform since, as you see, we are shorthanded. Gawain is still at work and we could no more play with one part tacit than a horse could canter shy one leg.

Speaker: ladies
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Perhaps I could offer as a poor but ready substitute a brief poetic recital. Though I don't pretend to great oratorical skills, I will happily present, with your ladies' permission, verse from the unquiet mind of Mr. Ed G'Allan Poe.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ..."Ladies, thy beauty is to me Like those Nicean barks of yore..."

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "That gently, o'er a perfumed sea The weary, wayworn wanderer bore To his own native shore... "

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "On desperate seas long wont to roam, Thy hyacinth hair, thy classic face, Thy Naiad airs have brought me home To the glory that was Greece And the grandeur that was Rome... "

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Mm-mm. Glory hallelujah.

Speaker: lady
Dialogue: That was soooome poem.

Speaker: lady
Dialogue: ...You know any?

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Y'all been celebratin'?.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Goodbye, ladies. We had such a pleasant time.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes indeed, and the thirst for knowledge is a very commendable thing. Though in this instance, I believe when you hear the explanation, you will laugh riotously, slappin' your knee and perhaps even wipin' away a giddy tear, relieved of your former concern.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: You see Lump here is an enthusiastic collector of Indian arrowheads and, having found one simply lying on your cellar floor, a particularly rare artifact of the Natchez tribe, he enlisted us in an all-out effort to sift through the subsoil in search of others. Well, in doing so, we apparently hit a motherlode of natural gas -- I myself became acutely aware of the smell of "rotten eggs" -- and it was at just this unfortunate moment that the General here violated one of the cardinal rules of this house and lit himself a cigarette.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: So sorry.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Ah. The money. The money is... Mr. Pancake's.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: He only just re-mortgaged his house in order to pay for the procedure that will correct the wandering eye of his common-law wife, Mountain Water, who suffers from astygmia and strabismus and a general curdling of the vitreous jelly. Mr. Pancake however is an ardent foe of the federal reserve and is in fact one of those eccentrics about whom one occasionally reads, hoarding his entire life savings either under the proverbial mattress or, as in Mr. Pancake's case, in a Hefty bag that is his constant companion.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Steel Sack.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Don't trust the banks. Never have.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madam -- if you please. Yes! Yes! It was a lie! A fantastic tale! You have us! Dead to rights! But please allow me to tell you the truth -- in private.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madam...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...What I am about to reveal to you, you may find... shocking. Mrs. Munson, I must tell you that we are not... what we appear.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: We are not in fact musicians of the late Renaissance. Nor of the early or mid period. We are, in fact... criminals! Desperate men, madam! We have tunneled into the nearby offices of the Lady Luck gambling emporium and have relieved it of its treasure!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: It is true that the Lady Luck is a den of iniquity, a painted harlot luring people into sin and exciting the vice of greed with her false promise of easy winnings. Oh, her gains are ill-gotten, yes, but I offer no excuses -- save one! We men have each pledged half of our share of the booty to a charitable institution -- the General, to a placement service for Southeast Asian refugees; Mr. Pancake to the Blue Ridge Parkway Conservancy; and Lump to the United Jewish Appeal. As compensation for use of your house we had planned to donate a full share to Bob Jones University, without burdening you with guilty knowledge by informing you of same. But you have wrested the information from me! Now it is all on the table. Now you have it, the whole story, the awful truth.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes, yes, shamefully I admit it, yes! But find the victim, Mrs. Munson, I challenge you! Even the casino itself, that riparian Gomorra, shall suffer no harm! It has an insurance company, a financial behemoth that will cheerfully replenish its depleted vaults! That is its function! And the insurance company itself is made up of tens and tens of thousands of policy-holders so that -- we have done the calculations, Mrs. Munson! -- so that at the end of the day, at the final reckoning, each policy- holder shall have contributed only one penny -- one single solitary cent -- to the satisfaction of this claim.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Think of it, Mrs. Munson! One cent from thousands upon thousands of people so that Bob Jones University can continue on its mission! Why, I have no doubt that, were the policy- holders aware of the existence of that august institution, why, each and every one of them would have volunteered some token amount to the furtherance of its aims!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes madam, sadly, the criminal stain is upon my soul, but the benefit shall accrue to any number of worthy causes. As long, that is, as the secret stays with us. And I, surely, shall not be the one to divulge it.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Excuse me, ma'am?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madam, I must strenuously protest--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Madam--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And... engage in divine worship?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: But--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Motherfuck!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes. Unfortunately, Mrs. Munson has rather complicated the situation--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I know how to discomplicate it! Put a cap in the old lady's head! Then everything simple again!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Not easy to do. Many reasons. Practical ones: a quiet neighborhood, a sleepy town. Reasons of moral repugnance: a harmless woman, a deed conceived and executed in cold blood. No, Gawain; would that it were simple!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Well -- fuck, man! What we gonna do, give the money back and go to church?!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I shudder. I quake.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...You sir, are a Buddhist. Is there not a middle way?

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Must float like a leaf on the river of life. And kill old lady.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well... I suppose you are right. It is the active nature of the crime, though, that so horrifies -- the squeezing of the trigger, the plunging of the knife. But, think a moment -- look at the other tools we have at hand.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...We have the cellar. We have masonry and trowel. Perhaps we could simply... immure her.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Sure, easiest thing in the world. I could whip up a little mortar in one of those snow saucers, lay the bricks, anchor in some chains, Mountain has a source for the manacles...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Ahh but gentlemen, we delude ourselves. Think of the woman's piteous moans as we lay tier upon tier of brick. Think of her lamentations as we fit the last brick into place, appealing to our better selves, the higher angels of our nature, our recollections of our own sainted mothers... No, I fear that we lack the sand to commit such an act. No... no... shortest and most painless is best. Let us confront reality. Gawain's gun... the retort muffled by a pillow... into the brain... the affair of an instant. The only question is... who wields the weapon.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...I believe it is traditional, in such circumstances, to draw straws.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, sure, fair enough.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I'm thinking, though, that since I lost my finger -- I mean, literally lost it because of that goddamn cat -- maybe I should be excused from this thing. Hard for me to squeeze a trigger anyway--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You one whiney motherfucker! I squeeze your nutsack you keep that up!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Listen, punk--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, no special pleading, no exceptions. It's in the nature of the situation that we would all prefer to be excused.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Well, okay... it was just a trial balloon...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Long straw. You all see it. All your fuss over nothing, punk.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: ...Motherfucker...

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: What you got there, Gawain?

Speaker: child gawain
Dialogue: Why -- nothin', mama.

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: Nothin' my ass! You got a dog there!

Speaker: child gawain
Dialogue: No, Mama!

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: A filthy noisy little pest of a puppy dog gonna shit all over the house!

Speaker: child gawain
Dialogue: He won't shit in the house, Mama, I'm gonna train him, I promise, gonna train him real good--

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: I'm gonna train you real good! I told you don't bring no stray dogs into this house!

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: ...You wait til your Daddy gets home, he gonna lay into you proper!

Speaker: child gawain
Dialogue: Please don't hurt me no more! I love you, Mama!

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: Daddy gonna kick your ass!

Speaker: mama
Dialogue: ...Bringin' in a filthy dirty dog!

Speaker: sister
Dialogue: Mama's whuppin' Gawain's ass!

Speaker: brother
Dialogue: Ain't you gonna use the strap, Mama?

Speaker: child gawain
Dialogue: Please don't hurt me, Mama!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I'm sorry, ma'am, I--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I can't do it!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Why... this is most... irregular.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: She reminds me of my mama. I can't shoot my mama! You motherfuckers just draw straws again.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Wait a minute. You've got to accept your responsibilities, young man.

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: Fuck you. And your irritated bowel. I can't shoot that old lady.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Must shoot!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Now look here, it's the easiest thing in the world. Pretend her head is a casaba melon, and the gun is a melon- baller, and--

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: What the fuck you talkin' about, man? You think this a melon-baller, you do it, man!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: My my, this is most irregular.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Look, with equal rights come equal responsibilities--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: I'm afraid that Mr. Pancake is right, my dear fellow. We cannot draw straws again; the exercise loses all credibility if you show that the loser can simply beg off doing the job.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Must shoot!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: She just an old colored lady to you -- you do it, man!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Why you sniveling little coward!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: What you say, you whiney motherfucker? I come up your irritated ass with this -- motherfuckin' gun--

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: You think you scare me, you mewling punk! You don't scare me! Bull Connor and all his dogs didn't scare me!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Be a man!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You fuck!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Be a man!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: You ain't no fuckin' man, fuckin' a sixty-year-old lady in pigtails!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: WHY YOU BASTARD PUNK! MOUNTAIN GIRL IS FIFTY-THREE!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...SHE COULD RIDE YOUR ASS TO JELLY!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Gentlemen, please!

Speaker: gawain
Dialogue: I seen Virginia hams I'd rather stick my dick in than your old--

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Oh my god...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I think he's hit!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...I'll just check the carotid artery.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...That's a negative.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Oh, fuck.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh my.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Is he dead, Professor?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Sure he's dead. I checked his carotid artery.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well this is most irregular. We will need a Hefty bag.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: She is in the kitchen. I shall distract her while you steal out with the carcass.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Well, my dear Mrs. Munson, I have outlined your position to my colleagues and I now return to you to return our collective verdict.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: There was much spirited discussion and an atmosphere of frank give-and- take. Some of our number were initially appalled at your proposal that we simply return the money; some were more receptive.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And that attitude, madam, was a factor in our discussions. To a man, I must say, they were devastated at the prospect of not being able to contribute to their respective charities.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Indeed. But at the end of the day, your position prevailed, and the men have decided that we shall return the money -- every last cent of it! -- and attend Sunday services, rather than spend the remainder of our years wasting away in the Mississippi Men's Correctional Facility. Though that was the original preference of some.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: So the money shall be returned tomorrow at the opening of the casino office. Enjoy your tea, madam...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...and congratulations on having recalled to the fold five poor, confused sheep who had momentarily strayed.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: They back yet?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Yes... yes, they just arrived.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Good. I'll go dump these in the hearse.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: What in heaven's name...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...General!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: No extra share, huh...

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Nnnrnf.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Oof!

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Mountain.

Speaker: mountain girl
Dialogue: Clark.

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: ...Nnrungh! Aaarmh... Ninnnff... Offffflleghhll...

Speaker: mountain girl
Dialogue: IBS, dear?

Speaker: pancake
Dialogue: Nnnnnmmmmfffgh!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "...Like those Nicean barks of yore That gently, o'er a perfumed sea..."

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Quick! Grab Clark!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "...The weary, wayworn wanderer bore... "

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "...To his own native shore."

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Excellent. I believe, at last, we have the right man for the job.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...T'was our at brought us to this pass...

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: What, Professor?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Our overweening pride... The old woman is a more potent antagonist than one had imagined...

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Now, Lump, I'm afraid it falls to you to finish the job.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...The comedy must end.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...Professor, I been doing some thinking.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh dear. Oh dear oh dear oh dear.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Maybe she's right! Maybe we should be going to church!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Oh dear, Lump. I feared that those would be your words. Not that I don't appreciate your giving the matter the benefit of your thought. But please recall, young man, our respective functions in this enterprise. I am a professor, the professor as you yourself so often say, the thinker, the "brains of the operation," trained in fact in the arts of cogitation. You, Lump, are the goon, the hooligan, the dumb brute whose actions must be directed by a higher intelligence.

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Yeah, I know, but--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: No buts, dear boy! Do not repeat the error of thinking! Now is the moment of praxis! Now, my dear boy, you must act!

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I can't do it, Professor! A nice old lady like that!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Think of the riches, Lump, that you and I alone shall divide! Recall the dream of wealth untold that first drew you to this enterprise!

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: But--

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: And reflect also that if you decline to act, forcing me to do so, then you shall no longer have any entitlement to the money! Your offices shall have been nugatory!

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: You mean -- you mean -- you're gonna kill her?!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Of course! My hand would be forced!

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: I can't let you do that, Professor! A nice old lady like that!

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: You?! Allow? Not allow? What presumption! You stupid boy! You very very extremely stupid boy!

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: Oh yeah?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...Well who looks stupid now?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...Huh?

Speaker: lump
Dialogue: ...No bullets?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: Perhaps... it had to be thus.

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "...Lo, in yon brilliant window-niche How statue-like I see thee stand..."

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Hm. A raven?

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: "...The agate lamp within thy hand... "

Speaker: dorr
Dialogue: ...Ah, Psyche! from the regions which Are Holy land!"

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Miz Munson.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Could it possibly wait, ma'am? We're a little busy today.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Call you right back.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: ...You know something about it?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: You... you have what at home, now?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Mm-hmm.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: How'd it get there, Marva?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Does he now.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Oh yes.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Angry, was he?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: I expect so.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: So you want us to go fetch him.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: ...Why don't you just keep it, Miz Munson.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: You keep it, Marva.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: How's that ma'am?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Yes ma'am?

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: That'd be nice, ma'am.

Speaker: sheriff wyner
Dialogue: Thank you for the information, ma'am.
